quotes.text: I'm a big proponent of asking myself, if I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing? How could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-reflection checklist that reframes communication failures as something you can proactively improve.

quotes.text: I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that small communication lapses can create outsized downstream costs across teams.

quotes.text: If you are just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people, and it's confusing, you didn't include information you should have included, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how a quick edit can prevent costly clarification loops and speed execution for many people at once.

quotes.text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable framework name for anticipating pushback before meetings or written proposals.

quotes.text: When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to spend a small amount of time pre-empting predictable questions to avoid feeling blindsided.

quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A practical heads-up for SaaS builders on when enterprise requirements typically emerge and what to anticipate.

quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Highlights a prioritization principle: reduce integration complexity to preserve time for core product work.

quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A concrete example of leveraging a proven, large-scale authorization model as a foundation for enterprise access control.

quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A specific adoption/cost data point that can materially affect build-vs-buy decisions for authentication/authorization.

quotes.text: When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: A succinct framing of why teams should plan early for security/compliance complexity rather than treating it as a later add-on.

quotes.text: I'm a big proponent of asking myself, "If I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing to that?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-audit question that shifts communication problems from blame to actionable personal improvement.

quotes.text: So I'm a big proponent of agency. And realizing that we can only control our own behavior.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A core mindset for influence: focus on what you can change (your clarity, framing, and delivery) rather than others’ reactions.

quotes.text: I think another big one that I teach in my course and really kick off with is practicing like it's game day, playing like it's game day.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable principle that reframes everyday stakeholder interactions as the real training ground for executive communication.

quotes.text: I see a lot of operators who save their best behavior for executives only.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that challenges the common habit of “turning it on” only for senior leadership.

quotes.text: I really see it as a means to an end where the end is getting the ideal outcome you're looking for.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A useful reframing that makes communication effectiveness measurable by outcomes (buy-in, decisions, next steps), not polish.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
quotes.text: So a common mistake that I see is overestimating the amount of buy-in that you have from your audience.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Highlights the root cause behind many stalled initiatives: assuming alignment before it’s been earned.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
quotes.text: A sales note is meant to get people excited to do the thing you want them to do, and to agree to do it. And only then after they have bought in, does it make sense to share the logistics.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Defines a clear sequencing framework (“sales then logistics”) practitioners can apply to messages and meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
quotes.text: So I actually think that you should always do a little bit of selling even for situations where people have generally bought in.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: even aligned stakeholders need a quick re-sell because attention and context decay fast.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
quotes.text: The other thing is, you can frame a conversation and sell a bit at the beginning very concisely. So I'm not talking about spending 15 minutes out of a 30 minute meeting selling, I'm talking about one to two minutes, even a couple sentences, and then transitioning into the main thing you want to talk about.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives an actionable time-boxed tactic for adding “why” without derailing speed-focused exec conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in first
quotes.text: Yeah. So I call it the yes, yes, yes, next, next, next mindset where if I'm listening to direct reports present something to me, very often I find myself thinking, "Got it. All right, yes, let's keep going." Right?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for how leaders process information, explaining why concise framing and clear asks matter.

quotes.text: And being concise is not about absolute word count, it's about economy of words. It's about the density of the insight that you're sharing.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Reframes concision as insight density rather than brevity, changing how you evaluate and edit communication.

quotes.text: And all of these pithy aphorisms assume that you actually know what your core point is. So you can't cut to the chase unless you know what the chase is. You can't unbury the lead unless you know what the lead is. And so that I found is the bottleneck to being concise.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Identifies the real constraint behind rambling: unclear thinking about the core point, not lack of editing discipline.

quotes.text: And so the only solution I found consistently to being concise is preparation.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives a practical lever—prep—to reliably improve concision in real-time conversations.

quotes.text: So if you even take 30 seconds to one minute to ground yourself on why am I in this meeting? What do I want to share and make sure I get across in the time that we have, you're going to go in there so much more focused and so much more able to be concise.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Provides a lightweight pre-meeting checklist that practitioners can apply immediately to reduce rambling.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
quotes.text: I also ask myself, how might I be adding cognitive load to whatever it is that I'm saying?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A simple self-check that reliably surfaces edits to make writing clearer and more concise.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
quotes.text: And usually if you even ask yourself that, your brain automatically comes up with stuff.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mechanism: the question itself triggers better editing without needing complex rules.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
quotes.text: There's a layer of advice under this that you're not saying that I'm going to say, which is actually look at the thing you wrote at least once before you share it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A high-leverage, easy-to-apply habit that prevents avoidable confusion and errors.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
quotes.text: I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why small improvements in clarity create outsized organizational leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load
quotes.text: So if you're just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people and it's confusing and you didn't include information you should have included, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. All 15 of these people are reading this being like, "Okay, what do I do with this?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Concrete example quantifying the hidden cost of unclear writing across many readers.

quotes.text: Signposting is using certain words, phrases, formatting, and an overall structure in your writing that helps guide your reader and signals what is coming in the rest of the post.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Defines the core concept of signposting as a practical tool for guiding readers through structure.

quotes.text: If you kick off sentences with signposting words, you can often signal, "Here's what I'm about to talk about in this paragraph."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: use specific lead-in phrases to create clarity without relying on heavy formatting.

quotes.text: I've seen memos where 30% of the note was bolded. And that just negates the entire point of bolding because if everything is bolded then nothing is being highlighted, right?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how excessive emphasis backfires and reduces signal-to-noise.

quotes.text: And it feels faster and more concise to put bullets and fragments, but a lot of times your reader on the other end of that is needing to decipher and interpret and guess what you actually meant. So it net, net takes longer.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point: “concise” fragments can increase total time by shifting work to the reader.

quotes.text: So that's I think a great litmus test of, "Was that idea fully thought out?" Because if it was, you should be able to really quickly turn it into a complete sentence.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Provides a simple test for clarity: if you can’t write it as a full sentence, the thinking may be incomplete.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: So I have a pretty first principles driven approach for this, which is to think about how long does it take me right now to get to the reaction I'm looking for from my recipient? If it takes a bunch of back and forth and a bunch of friction, then that's my baseline. And once you start practicing some of these communication skills, how does that speed up? If you would have had seven different touch points of back and forth, does that shrink to two to three?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A measurable feedback loop for communication: track “speed to desired reaction” and use it as a baseline to improve.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: So, I would approach it with a hypothesis-driven experimental mindset and almost like a game. Like, "When I do this, how does that other person react? If I frame it this way, do I get a different reaction? When I try this, am I able to cut through the noise more?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Treat communication improvement as iterative experimentation—test framing changes and observe reactions.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: And I will say that the way not to do it is to try to incorporate 30 different tactics at the same time and then beat yourself up when you don't remember to do them.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical warning against overloading yourself—focus on one tactic at a time to build durable habits.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: The problem with that line of thinking is that no one instance of something is ever going to feel important enough to spend a little bit more time on that. And then, but when you zoom out, that's like, "Well that's all your work then. This is literally everything you've touched. This is all your work output then."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: small communication artifacts feel trivial individually, but collectively they *are* your output.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: I like thinking about it as a little bit more upfront investment. And it is an investment. It's not just time. It's an investment because yes, it takes a little bit longer to make a Slack message a little bit better, but net, net if you save a bunch of questions and back and forth and people asking you things that you don't think they should be asking, then by investing a little bit of upfront effort, you've prevented all that from happening.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A cost-benefit model for writing: spend more effort upfront to reduce downstream clarification cycles.

quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work and your vision is clear. You know exactly who's doing what and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete picture of what “good alignment” looks like at the start of a project—clear ownership and easy access to needed information.

quotes.text: In fact, you don't have to waste time searching for anything because everything your team needs from project trackers and OKRs to documents and spreadsheets lives in one tab all in Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable operational principle: reduce coordination cost by centralizing key artifacts (trackers, OKRs, docs, spreadsheets) in one place.

quotes.text: And more than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals broad usage and perceived value for alignment and focus.

quotes.text: she said you had zero half-baked thoughts, 100% complete sentences, perfect punctuation, clear takeaways at the top of every message.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable standard for written communication in Slack: lead with takeaways and write with clarity and completeness.

quotes.text: It's the kind of thing you don't notice in isolation, but once you see everyone else's messages in a remote-first company, it's a stark contrast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that communication quality becomes dramatically more visible—and differentiating—in remote-first environments.

quotes.topic_title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
quotes.text: It's the kind of thing you don't notice in isolation, but once you see everyone else's messages in a remote-first company, it's a stark contrast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights how writing quality becomes a visible differentiator at scale, especially in remote-first environments.

quotes.topic_title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
quotes.text: I feel like I get a pretty good response rate pretty quickly for the things that I ask for, for the recommendations I'm making.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Connects clearer communication to a practical outcome practitioners care about: faster, better responses.

quotes.topic_title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
quotes.text: over time I've realized that improving my communication has led to people receiving my ideas better.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A simple causal model: invest in communication quality to increase idea adoption and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
quotes.text: It's like a couple more minutes on the Slack message, a couple more minutes on email.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes a low-effort, high-leverage habit—small upfront time investments that compound in outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Slack writing standards and compounding leverage
quotes.text: There's no magic here, it's just spend a little more time and use some of these tactics that we're talking about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Demystifies persuasive communication as a repeatable practice rather than innate talent.

quotes.topic_title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: So I'm a big proponent of speaking accurately. You can avoid a lot of problems if you speak accurately about your level of conviction and about the actual amount of evidence that you have for something.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A crisp principle for calibrating confidence by matching your language to your true certainty and evidence level.

quotes.topic_title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: It's okay for something to be an initial hunch. Say, "It's an initial hunch." Don't act like this is something that you are super sure about.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on explicitly labeling uncertainty to prevent others from over-weighting your claims.

quotes.topic_title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: And y'all might spend real headcount and dollars pursuing something that you have advocated for in a way where you overreached with your level of confidence.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Highlights the concrete organizational cost of presenting hypotheses as facts.

quotes.topic_title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: And so again, speaking accurately, if you have really strong reasons to recommend something to the cross-functional team, it's almost irresponsible to act like you are not really sure and it's just this random idea, "Hey, try it if you want to."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point that underconfidence can be as harmful as overconfidence when the stakes are high.

quotes.topic_title: Calibrating confidence: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: Yeah, I think sharing a point of view, sharing a recommendation, and then backing it up with evidence, with logic, with first principles, with examples, with data, if you have it.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical methodology for persuasive communication: lead with a POV, then support it with multiple forms of reasoning.
